definitions.definition: used after a verb or preposition to mean ‘in, at or to this position or place’

examples.text: I live here.
Put the box here.
Click here for more details.
Let's get out of here.
Come over here.

definitions.definition: used when you are giving or showing something to somebody

examples.text: Here's the money I promised you.
Here's a dish that is simple and quick to make.
Here is your opportunity.
**Here comes** the bus.
I can't find my keys. Oh, **here they are**.
**Here we are** *(= we've arrived)*.

definitions.definition: used to show your role in a situation

examples.text: I'm here to help you.
The countdown to Christmas **starts here**.
Here the speaker paused to have a drink.
Come by here now!

definitions.definition: the present time; at the present time

examples.text: our obsession with the here and now
We're going to settle this here and now.
Papers were scattered here and there on the floor.

definitions.definition: used when you are telling people that you are just going to do something exciting, dangerous, etc.

examples.text: ‘Here goes,’ said Grace and took a deep breath.

definitions.definition: used to wish somebody health or success, as you lift a glass and drink a toast

examples.text: Here's to your future happiness!

definitions.definition: in many different places; all around
said when something is starting to happen

examples.text: ‘Here we go,’ thought Fred, ‘she's sure to say something.’

definitions.definition: said when something is starting to happen again, especially something bad
used when you are giving something to somebody

examples.text: Here you are. This is what you were asking for.

definitions.definition: used when you are giving something to somebody

examples.text: Here you go. Four copies, is that right?
What might have happened is neither here nor there.
As soon as I get my money I'm out of here!

wordOrigin: Old English hēr, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German hier, also to he.
